Patch Set 18: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 8eb20f282bb52dc40bccf336ecb0feb0882e24df
DSP0248
Updated.
manojkiran.eda@gmail.com do you have any comment in this Patch set?

we could add a check for transfer operation flag as well {Possible values: {GetNextPart=0x00, GetFirstPart=0x01, AcknowledgementOnly=0x02}}, and return INVALID DATA if the value is not present in the enum.
Updated.

we could even check the combinations:

1. null & getfirstpart 
2. 0xFFFF & getnextpart 

and return INVALID_DATA if the combinations are not correct.
Updated.
magic numbers. please avoid these and have some # defines to denote what these are.
Added "#define PLDM_POLL_FOR_PLATFORM_EVENT_MESSAGE_CHECKSUM_BYTES 4" to define the data size of checksum.
please also add the relevant test cases for the additional checks that I mentioned in the other file.
Updated.
A couple of minor comments.

Can we please put the variable declarations at the top of the function as is typical with C code (unlike C++).

I know C can do mixed declarations these days, but let's try to keep things consistent.
Updated.
Unnecessary as `data_transfer_handle` isn't dereferenced below.
Updated.
How does the caller know how much of the buffer is populated with data?
Do the caller really need that? If it is then we have to add the allocated size fields in pldm_msgbuf. With "remaining" and "length" fields the caller can know the populated buffer.

I meant the caller of `encode_poll_for_platform_event_message_resp()`, who doesn't have access to the `struct pldm_msgbuf` instance, let alone the length data. How does this work when the `struct pldm_msg` buffer gets passed to the transport APIs? How they know how much of the buffer to transmit?

When the event_id is 0xffff or 0x0000, the payload_length will be 4.
I added code to checking that condition. In that case, the APIs will protect itself with invalid input.

Okay, I think your latest update resolves the problem. The caller has to know the length given the value for `event_id` that they pass in. That's at least something. We can defer thinking about how to make that more ergonomic for now because I suspect this approach is used in other places as well?
Hah, we raced our replies there. Marking this as resolved.
We can do this check at line 1010 right? That's no need to do any of the work above if this check fails?
This check require the event_data_size which only has after 1018 line.
Ack
Oh, sorry. This is encode function so event_data_size is known. Let me update the code.
A couple of minor cleanups suggested. Otherwise looks good

For insert I can't immediately think of a need to check the return value. It's different to the extract case where we need to prevent ourselves from dereferencing a pointer to uninitialized memory. For the "encode" functions we know e.g. `event_id` must be initialized as it was passed as an argument to the function. So we can remove this check.
Updated.
Also remove this check.
Updated.
Also remove this check.
Updated.
